articles.summary: The Trump administration is cutting federal spending at the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA). About 10% of NOAA's workforce could be impacted, with several hundred layoffs anticipated. Charles Konrad, a professor at UNC-Chapel Hill and the director of the NOAA-funded Southeast Regional Climate Center, is worried about the future of the agency.

articles.title: Charlottetown report sounds the alarm on how climate change will hammer the city
articles.summary: A report by the City of Charlottetown details how extreme weather is expected to take a toll on the city in the decades to come. Rising sea levels will affect downtown buildings downtown and extreme heat events will be more common, according to the report. CBC's Cody MacKay explains the report and what comes next.

articles.title: Climate action demands global fraternity
articles.author: Gulf-Times
articles.summary: The existential threat of the climate crisis casts a long shadow over our planet. Vulnerable countries, particularly small island developing states (SIDS) like mine, are on the front lines. We need to act now to prevent the climate change from affecting these countries.

articles.title: Climate change is driving earlier springs
articles.author: WRAL
articles.summary: Data shows winter is warming nationwide, with spring arriving earlier and lasting longer. Scientists say climate change is driving the trend, leading to fewer cold snaps and more unpredictable temperature swings.      .   "Climate change" is driving earlier springs.

articles.title: US scientists rebuild climate risk map deleted from government site
articles.author: James Dinneen

articles.title: As Ugandans feel the heat, COU launches Environmental Month
articles.author: Benjalina Namazzi
articles.summary: The current extreme heat felt across most of Uganda and beyond has drawn attention to what scientists are pointing to as global warming. There is an urgent need for action to prevent the planet warming further, according to scientists.      . .

articles.title: Birds That Live Long and Slow May Be More Vulnerable to Climate Change, Research Finds
articles.author: Kiley Price
articles.summary: As climate change accelerates, birds that live in areas with higher temperature variability within a year have shorter lifespans, reproducing early and often. Longer-lived avian species tend to live longer in environments that are more variable year-to-year. Long-lived bird species that are experiencing rapid rates of temperature and precipitation change in environments traditionally been less variable are most vulnerable to global warming.

articles.title: Pinellas County leaders urge need for easements in Sand Key beach nourishment project
articles.author: Mary O'Connell
articles.summary: Pinellas County leaders are pressing property owners to sign construction easements for the Sand Key beach nourishment project. The deadline was initially Friday, but Pinellas officials will accept signed easements that come in over the weekend. Without the easements, nourishment won't happen in Indian Rocks Beach, Indian Shores, and Redington Shores.

articles.title: Australia's 2024-25 summer likely ‘the third or fourth hottest on record', with Sydney, Perth and Brisbane much warmer than the long-term average
articles.author: Rob Sharpe
articles.summary: It was the third or fourth hottest summer on record in Australia. Melbourne had its hottest summer in 12 years. Adelaide and Hobart had their hottest summer since 2018-19. Canberra had the hottest since the 2019-20 Black Summer. Sydney had the sixth wetter than usual summer in a row, Canberra the third, Brisbane the second, Hobart the wettest in a decade. The split of wetter and drier than usual regions was 50/50.

articles.title: Sundre area sets new temperature record for February 27
articles.author: Sheldon Spackman
articles.summary: 13.1 degrees Celsius set a new temperature record for February 27 in the Sundre, AB, area on Thursday. The old record high was 10.6 degrees set in 2006. The records in this area have been kept since 1993. The thermometer hit 13.1 degree Celsius on Thursday, beating the old record.

articles.title: Extreme heat can accelerate aging: Research
articles.author: TOI Lifestyle Desk
articles.summary: The more days of intense heat a participant endured, the faster they aged. Longer periods of extreme heat accelerated ageing in older people by more than two years. As the climate heats up, humans will be exposed to more and more heat and their bodies will respond to these stresses by ageing faster.

articles.title: NOAA cuts spark outrage amid fears of climate science rollback
articles.author: Scott Broom
articles.summary: At least 800 NOAA employees were fired as part of a sweeping round of cuts. The agency is responsible for the National Weather Service, climate research, and fisheries management. Jonathan Nash, a 23-year-old marine scientist, was one of the employees dismissed. The Heritage Foundation's Project 2025 called NOAA 'one of the main drivers of the climate change alarm industry' and advocated for privatizing weather forecasting.

The position was supposed to be filled in 2023, but was cut from the budget and approved in last year's budget. It cost $100,000 and Burns started in her new role on February 3. She will focus on the town's climate change adaptation plan, the invasive species management plan, natural assets management strategy and coastal protection program.

articles.title: NOAA firings affect Boulder office

The government has $36 trillion in debt and $1.8 trillion deficit.

articles.summary: About 800 employees with the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration have been terminated. Probationary employees were terminated Thursday. articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: The Trump administration fired more than 800 employees at the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration. The cuts are part of President Donald Trump's strategy to downsize the federal government.

articles.title: Scientists figure out when next ice age will happen — except humans likely changed everything
articles.author: Study Finds Staff
articles.summary: In a world free from human influence, Earth would begin sliding into another ice age roughly 10,000 years from now. This prediction comes from research that has finally deciphered the mysterious rhythm governing our planet's glacial cycles over the past million years. Three specific orbital cycles control the timing of Earth's ice ages with remarkable precision.

articles.title: MSM Ignore New Research Confirming Ocean Currents Are Stable
articles.author: Thomas Richard
articles.summary: For decades, mainstream media outlets have warned that the Atlantic Meridional Overturning Circulation (AMOC) is on the verge of collapse, bringing catastrophic consequences to the planet. Two recent peer-reviewed studies confirm that the AMOC has remained stable for at least 60 years and is unlikely to collapse in the foreseeable future.

articles.title: 'Like a warm bath': coral reefs rocked by heatwave
articles.author: Poppy Johnston
articles.summary: Coral reefs off Australia's wildest stretch of coastline may be spared from agricultural runoff and other pressures from nearby human activity, but there is no escape from global warming-intensified marine heatwaves, according to the scientists.

articles.title: Allergy sufferers beware: B.C. to see intense pollen season
articles.author: Class
articles.summary: Vancouver, Burnaby and Victoria will see a significant spike in pollen this weekend and in the weeks ahead. Cold weather had held the pollen count at bay until recently, but warmer weather triggers a 'rapid increase' in airborne allergens. It's a late start for pollen season in B.C. this year, but it's still earlier than the rest of the country.

articles.title: Earth's Next Ice Age Might Already Be on the Way—Here's What Scientists Just Discovered
articles.author: Lydia Amazouz
articles.summary: Next ice age could arrive within 11,000 years, according to a new study published in Science. Earth's orbital cycles influence the start and end of glacial periods. Human activity is already disrupting Earth's natural climate cycles. If emissions continue at their current rate, they could delay or even override the natural timing of the next ice age.

articles.title: OCHA: Recent floods in Afghanistan kill 22
articles.author: Fidel Rahmati
articles.summary: The recent floods in Afghanistan have killed at least 22 people and injured 16 others. The floods have destroyed more than 270 homes across 13 provinces of Afghanistan. The humanitarian agencies are working to provide immediate relief, including food, shelter, and medical aid, while addressing the long-term needs of the displaced.

articles.title: Extreme heat may be accelerating aging in older adults: Study
articles.author: The Hill
articles.summary: Extreme heat may be speeding up the aging process in older adults. More than 100 million Americans will be affected by extreme heat events in 2050. The frequency, intensity and duration of heat events are expected to grow rapidly in the coming decades, according to the study.

articles.title: Changing climate hits winter tourism in Battagram
articles.author: Sheraz Ahmad Sherazi
articles.summary: This year's winter tourism in Battagram has been severely affected due to changing weather patterns, unexpected temperature fluctuations and damaged infrastructure. Businesses that rely on winter tourism, such as hotels, restaurants, and transport services, are struggling. Health risks associated with unpredictable weather patterns are also a concern.

articles.title: 3 million people displaces in Afghanistan due to Climate Disasters, 11 million at risk, warns IOM

articles.summary: Nearly 9 million people in Afghanistan have been affected by climate-related disasters in the past year. Nearly 3 million people have been displaced in Afghanistan due to climate disasters since 2021, with 988,000 experiencing temporary displacement in 2024 alone. 11 million people remain at high risk of severe climate impacts in Afghanistan, especially in vulnerable provinces.

The layoffs have drawn criticism from scientists and lawmakers.

articles.title: Scientists warn of giant tsunamis from Antarctic glacier melt
articles.author: Alimat Aliyeva
articles.summary: Scientists have predicted the potential for giant tsunamis caused by the melting of glaciers in Antarctica. Underwater landslides triggered by climate change could lead to massive waves. Researchers drilled into seabed cores and discovered loose layers of sediment that have previously generated massive waves in the ocean. These waves affected the coasts of South America, New Zealand and Southeast Asia.

articles.title: 8 of 10 Americans who experienced severe winter weather see climate change at work, AP-NORC poll shows

About 7 in 10 adults who live in the Midwest experienced severe cold in the past five years, compared with about half of residents of the South and Northeast and about one-third of those in the West. About half of adults under age 30 believe climate change will impact them personally.

articles.author: Caitlin Fitzsimmons
articles.summary: It was the second-warmest January since records began in 1910 for Australia. It was wetter than usual for parts of the country's east and north-west, but drier than average for the south and central areas. The highest daytime temperature of the summer anywhere in the country was 49.3 degrees at Geraldton Airport in the Mid West of Western Australia on January 20. The wettest day of summer was February 3 at Paluma Ivy Cottage in Queensland, which recorded 745.2mm of rain in one day. Australia has had seven tropical cyclones in our region this season.

articles.title: A looming ice age? Scientists find a striking pattern in Earth's history.
articles.author: Jeanine Santucci
articles.summary: An ice age should begin in about 10,000 years, but its onset is most likely delayed due to man-made climate change. Scientists have long known that how Earth orbits the sun influence glacial cycles over thousands of years. This analysis is the first time anyone has been able to determine which orbital characteristic has the most influence on the start and end of ice ages. The period we live in now, called the Holocene, began some 11,700 years ago.

articles.summary: As extreme weather events intensify, more people are forced to flee their homes. Dr Patel credited the expansion of green areas and water bodies in Dubai for the apparent fall in surface temperatures.

articles.title: Poll shows climate change affecting work
articles.author: Spectrum News Staff
articles.summary: 8 in 10 U.S. adults say they have experienced some kind of extreme weather in recent years. About half of them have been personally affected by severe cold weather or severe winter storms. Midwesterners are most likely to feel the brunt of the cold weather. About 7 in 10 adults believe climate change is occurring.

articles.title: India records warmest February in 124 years since 1901 with average temperature above…
articles.author: Pravrajya Suruchi
articles.summary: India has experienced its hottest February in 124 years. The average temperature rose above 22 degrees Celsius. February 2025 was the second warmest on record, just behind February 2023. For the first time ever, the average minimum temperature crossed 15 degrees Celsius, making it the warmest February night temperatures recorded.

articles.title: Most Americans who experienced severe winter weather see climate change at work, AP-NORC poll shows
articles.author: Beaumont Enterprise
articles.summary: A new poll finds that most U.S. adults who say severe cold was among the types of extreme weather they experienced in recent years cite climate change as a cause. This indicates that many understand that global warming is a cause of such extreme weather events.

articles.title: Most Americans who experienced severe winter weather see climate change at work, AP-NORC poll shows
articles.author: Associated Press
articles.summary: 8 in 10 U.S. adults say they have experienced some kind of extreme weather in recent years, according to a new poll from The Associated Press-NORC Center for Public Affairs Research. About half of adults under 30 believe climate change will have a major impact on their lives.

articles.title: Most Americans who experienced severe winter weather see climate change at work, AP-NORC poll shows
articles.summary: Matt Ries has lived in Florida for three years. Last summer was unusually hot, followed by three hurricanes, and then temperatures dropped below freezing for days this winter. To Ries, the extreme weather bore all the hallmarks of climate change. Ries is an Ohio native now in Tampa.

articles.title: Most Americans who experienced severe winter weather see climate change at work, AP-NORC poll shows
articles.author: Tammy Webber
articles.summary: A new poll finds that most U.S. adults who say severe cold was among the types of extreme weather they experienced in recent years cite climate change as a cause. Most of them say it was caused by climate change.    iReport.com:

articles.title: Most Americans who experienced severe winter weather see climate change at work, AP-NORC poll shows
articles.author: TAMMY WEBBER
articles.summary: 8 in 10 U.S. adults say they have experienced some kind of extreme weather in recent years, according to a new poll from The Associated Press-NORC Center for Public Affairs Research. About 7 in 10 adults who live in the Midwest experienced severe cold in the past five years, compared with about half of residents of the South and Northeast and about one-third of those in the West.

articles.title: The Best Places to Visit in a Warming World
articles.author: Jan Otte
articles.summary: As the planet continues to warm, the landscapes and attractions around us are transforming in unexpected ways. From the shifting sands of deserts to the melting glaciers, these places are not just destinations but stories of our evolving Earth. Join us as we explore the best places to visit in a warming world.

articles.title: Frozen for centuries, bizarre artifacts emerge from Norway's melting glaciers!
articles.author: The Times
articles.summary: As glaciers melt due to climate change, they are uncovering long-lost artifacts. In Norway, glacial archaeology is at the forefront of the field, because of the country's history-making glaciers.   Â   in Norway.

articles.title: CLIMATE CHANGE: A THREATENING REALITY
articles.author: Muhammad Mujtaba Khan
articles.summary: Climate change is a global issue. Pakistan is among the top ten countries most affected by climate change. Developed countries need the support of wealthier nations through financial aid and technology transfer to withstand its devastating impact. Pakistan should adopt public-friendly policies to promote the use of renewable energy sources and develop climate-resilient infrastructure.

articles.title: ‘Gulf of America' now on all FWC commission materials
articles.author: Ashley Suter
articles.summary: The Florida Fish and Wildlife Conservation Commission has changed the name of the Gulf of Mexico to 'Gulf of America' in support of President Donald Trump's executive order. The Gulf provides recreational and economic opportunities through fishing, boating, tourism and other outdoor pursuits.

articles.title: Around 600 workers have been laid off by the American 🇺🇸 National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration
articles.author: Thread starter
articles.summary: About 600 people were let go by the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) as part of the Trump administration's efforts to reduce federal agencies. The NOAA reductions follow a broader pattern of federal employment losses during the Trump's administration. The Department of Agriculture, the Department of Energy, the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA), and Department of the Interior are among the other agencies impacted.

articles.title: Research Voyage Targets Denman Glacier's Changes 2025
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: RSV Nuyina's first dedicated marine science voyage will study the Denman Glacier, in East Antarctica, from the sea. The glacier has retreated 5km in just over two decades and scientists want to know what that accelerated melt rate could mean for global sea levels and regional biodiversity in future.

articles.title: Scientists issue warning to public about 'high-risk' events that could demolish local economies: 'Remember the effect on people'
articles.author: Timothy McGill
articles.summary: Winters are getting shorter in Canada and warmer in the United States. Rising winter temperatures are raising the risk of ice storms. The tourism industry that relies on snow is taking an economic hit. Cooling off our warming world will mean a shift from dirty energy sources to cleaner, renewable options.

articles.title: Breeders come to disturbing conclusion after noticing changes in dogs: 'They have become less active'
articles.author: Chloe Bryant
articles.summary: As global temperatures rise, breeders in Turkey have noticed a change in the fur color of Kangal dogs. They have become less active in the heat, increased their water intake, and sought out cooler, shaded areas. Their appetite has decreased as they conserve energy, prioritizing shelter over activity.

articles.title: ARC Ltd. and IFC Forge Partnership to Shield African Agriculture from Climate Risks
articles.summary: ARC Ltd. and the International Finance Corporation announced a collaboration aimed at mitigating climate-related risks for farmers and agribusinesses. The partnership seeks to unlock investment in a sector critical to the continent's food security and economic stability. Agriculture sustains nearly 60% of Africa's workforce and contributes over 15% to its GDP. The World Bank warns that Africa must ramp up food production by 70% by 2050.

articles.title: Bangladesh faces billion-dollar annual losses as marine heatwaves intensify: Study
articles.author: TBS Report
articles.summary: Bangladesh is experiencing severe economic and environmental consequences due to the increasing intensity of marine heatwaves. Annual losses from cyclone-related damages exceeding $1 billion. The report highlights the urgent need for a transition to renewable energy sources to mitigate these escalating climate threats.

articles.title: Surge in marine heatwaves costs lives and billions in storm damage – study
articles.author: AOL
articles.summary: The world's oceans experienced three-and-a-half times as many marine heatwave days last year and in 2023 compared with any other year on record. The sustained spike in ocean temperatures cost lives and caused billions of dollars of damage to the marine ecosystems.

articles.title: Significant rise in flood frequency in High Mountain Asia since 2000 due to climate change: Study
articles.author: PTI
articles.summary: The frequency of floods in High Mountain Asia has increased significantly since 2000 due to climate change, according to a new study. The study analysed 1,015 floods since 1950. Since 1950, the region's average temperature has shown a steady rise, warming at a rate of 0.3 degrees Celsius per decade. Human activities are making flood risks worse.

articles.title: 'Don't forget us': Bat Cave residents decry 'disaster tourists,' comment on recovery plan
articles.author: Ryley Ober
articles.summary: Tropical Storm Helene hit Henderson County, North Carolina, on September 27, flooding and landslides. Five months later, the community of Bat Cave is still struggling to recover from the damage caused by the storm. Road reconstruction is taking a long time. The U.S. Postal Service said it could be another 30 days before mail arrives in Bat Cave again, but officials are pushing for sooner.

articles.title: Photos: What Bat Cave looks like 5 months after Tropical Storm Helene
articles.summary: Tropical Storm Helene hit the area of Bat Cave on February 25, 2025. Lynette Staton continues to head up the Bat Cave Disaster Relief Center at the site of her badly damaged shop, Hip Hen Uniques. Edneyville resident Tracy Brevard worked on the roof of the post office. The site has become a community hub and distribution center after the storm.

articles.title: Last month was unseasonably chilly for SC. Globally, it was the hottest January on record.
articles.author: Jonah Chester
articles.summary: It was the coldest January for the contiguous United States since 1988. It was the sixth driest January on average for South Carolina. Globally, January was the hottest January on NOAA's 176-year record. South Carolina will likely see above-average temperatures through May.

articles.title: The ENSO cycle: How El Niño and La Niña impact Connecticut's climate
articles.author: Tim McGill
articles.summary: El Niño and La Niña are different phases of the El Niño-Southern Oscillation cycle. El Niño happens when sea surface temperatures are warmer than average in the same region of the Pacific. La Niñas tend to correspond to relatively cooler months. This January was warmer than January of 2024 when an El Niño was occurring. The latest ENSO update has forecasters estimating a 66% chance of a switch to neutral conditions during the period of March through May.

articles.title: CARICOM extends ‘25 by 2025' food security initiative to 2030, adds new goals
articles.author: Monica Walker
articles.summary: President Irfaan Ali announces new goals added to CARICOM's agriculture and food security initiative. The 25 by 2025 initiative targeted the reduction of the Caribbean's region's more than $6 billion food import bill by 25 percent by year-end has now been extended to 2030.

articles.title: Climate change and pollution threaten 'sacred' Ganga
articles.summary: Climate change and pollution threaten'sacred' Ganga. Religious leaders and experts say there may not be another 144-year 'Mahakumbh' under business as usual scenario. The current scenario does not suit them.   They are concerned about the future of the Ganga and its water supply.

articles.title: Studies have shown that the amount of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere that plants are absorbing con..
articles.author: A High-Ranking Official
articles.summary: Scientists are observing carbon dioxide in the atmosphere to measure the risk of global warming. Since 1958, the concentration of carbon dioxide has been measured. The concentration rose from 0.03% to 0.04% since 1958. The recent rise in temperature is getting steeper. The ability of plants to absorb carbon dioxide from the atmosphere has reached its limit.

articles.title: After devastation, Suncoast now grapples Cat. 5 economic storm
articles.author: Lily Fox/Suncoast Searchlight
articles.summary: Ed Chiles ran waterfront restaurants on the shores of Anna Maria Island and Longboat Key for nearly half a century. His restaurants specialized in sustainable seafood and farm-fresh produce. The story was produced by Suncoast Searchlight, a nonprofit newsroom serving Sarasota, Manatee, and DeSoto counties.

articles.title: Evicted By Water: Bayelsa Community At The Mercy Of Atlantic Ocean Surge
articles.author: Pauline Onyibe
articles.summary: The Atlantic Ocean's tributary in Sangana community, Brass Local Government Area of Bayelsa State, overflows, devouring houses and displacing residents. Many have lost their homes and properties to the sea surge. The shoreline protection project awarded 15 years ago has not been completed. The project was awarded to Zomay Maritime Integrated Services in 2009.

articles.title: Spectre of hunger hovers again over Somalia as drought and conflict put 4.4 million at risk
articles.summary: Nearly 4.4 million people will be at risk of hunger in Somalia by June, according to a UN-supported report. The Horn of Africa nation is one of the world's poorest, enduring decades of civil war, a bloody insurgency by the al-Qaeda-linked Al-Shabaab and frequent climate disasters.

articles.title: Surf Life Saving WA records twelve drownings as West Aussies swelter through hottest summer on record
articles.author: The West Australian
articles.summary: It's been a warm summer in Western Australia. The Bureau of Meteorology predicts a warmer autumn. Lifeguards and lifesavers have rescued 773 beachgoers since December 1. Surf Life Saving WA has seen a 160 per cent increase since the previous summer. The most recent drowning came on Monday at Scarborough Beach.

articles.title: Hotter weather on way as life savers reveal surge in rescues
articles.author: The West Australian
articles.summary: It's been a warm summer in Western Australia. The Bureau of Meteorology predicts a warmer autumn. Lifeguards and lifesavers have rescued 773 beachgoers since December 1. 12 people have drowned off the coast of WA this summer with 770 swimmers rescued from local beaches. Surf Life Saving WA manager Cam Robbins warned swimmers to stay vigilant.

articles.title: Honeybees for food security: The way forward
articles.summary: Climate change poses significant challenges to achieving global food security. About 400 crop species rely on honeybee pollination for their economic and ecological significance. Pollination services contributed USD 477 million to Nepal's agricultural revenue in 2018, primarily from vegetable and fruit production. About 70% of the 75 different crops cultivated in Nepal depend on insect pollination.

articles.title: Eastern North Carolina remains in moderate to severe drought
articles.author: Pre News
articles.summary: There has been no improvement in the drought status in eastern North Carolina. Areas of Onslow, Jones, Carteret, Craven and Pamlico Counties nearer the coast remain in severe drought. A moderate to high fire danger is in place through the weekend.

articles.title: Research Links Climate Change to Extreme Cold Events
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: In December 2023, eastern China was hit by an unexpected extreme cold event that caused transportation shutdowns, power supply shortages and agricultural damage. A new study led by Qian Cheng from the Chinese Academy of Sciences and the University at Albany examined the 2023 event to better understand how the warming effect of climate change drives or suppresses these types of extreme cold waves. They found that the event could be attributed to unusual large-scale atmospheric circulation, which accounted for 83 percent of its intensity. The warming effect reduced the event's severity by up to 22 percent.

articles.title: Ghana's climate action: complex but necessary task
articles.author: GTonline
articles.summary: The main greenhouse gases that cause climate change as a result of industrial activities are carbon dioxide and methane. The world struggles to cope with global warming, erratic rainfall, drought, flooding, rise in sea level, green­house gas emissions and loss of carbon sinks. Ghana is a signatory to the Paris Agreement that seeks to prevent global temperatures from rising more than 1.5 degrees.

articles.title: Japanese chum salmon population in danger from climate change and rival pink salmon
articles.summary: Chum salmon in Hokkaido, northern Japan, are in decline due to climate change. Professor Masahide Kaeriyama warns there will be no more salmon in Japan in the next century. Maruichi Suisan has increased the price of salmon jerky by 20% this winter.

articles.title: Amazing Xinjiang: Ili River transformed by spring frost
articles.author: CGTN
articles.summary: Rising temperatures are melting the frozen ice on the Ili River near Cocodala City in northwest China's Xinjiang Uygur Autonomous Region. Viewed from above, the rime-covered vegetation along the river resembles a white forest.

articles.title: ‘Who is in charge?': PM has ‘no clue' what is going on with Chinese warships
articles.summary: Several commercial flights were rerouted following live fire drills from Chinese warships off the coast of Australia last week. Sky News host Danica De Giorgio has slammed Prime Minister Anthony Albanese's 'floundering' on the issue of national security. She asks who is in charge right now?

articles.title: Mountains at Risk: Rising Floods in High Mountain Asia
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: Flood occurrences in High Mountain Asia have risen significantly since 2000, mainly as a result of climate change, according to a new study by scientists including Sonam Wangchuk. The research analyzed 1,015 flood events since 1950, revealing an increase in frequency and unpredictability in timing.

articles.title: Scientists Link Ice Age Cycles to Orbital Shifts
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: A new analysis suggests the onset of the next ice age could be expected in 10,000 years' time. The study tracks the natural cycles of the planet's climate over a million years. It offers new insights into Earth's dynamic climate system and a step-change in understanding glacial cycles. The team plans to build on their findings to create a baseline of the Earth's natural climate for the next 10,00 years.

articles.title: Research Suggests Predictability of Earth's Climate Shifts
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: Study tracks the natural cycles of the planet's climate over a million years. It predicts the onset of the next ice age could be expected in 10,000 years' time. It is based on a new interpretation of the small changes in Earth's orbit of the Sun.

articles.title: Talk is cheap, hey Andrew. Time for real action on climate
articles.author: Jo Dodds
articles.summary: In the aftermath of the Black Summer fires, BSCA co-founded Bushfire Survivors for Climate Action with dozens of other survivors. They want to do more to prevent the devastation of thousands and thousands of lives in the next bushfires. They have run two legal cases, won a shift in NSW law and travelled to COP twice to speak on the international stage about impacts on communities and the need for urgent emissions reductions. This week they went to Sydney to commemorate the five-year anniversary of Black Summer Fires with an event at the Australian Museum. They invited Liberal candidate for Gilmore Andrew Constance to this event. He didn't reply.

articles.title: Weatherwatch: marine ‘hot spot' could change makeup of British fish species
articles.author: Paul Brown
articles.summary: UK waters, particularly the southern North Sea, are warming fast. Fishers are travelling further north to catch British favourites such as cod and haddock and some salmon stocks face extinction. The increasing acidity of the seas caused by greater carbon dioxide absorption might kill some marine species and the melting Arctic ice has the potential to switch off vital currents such as the Gulf Stream.

articles.title: MP weather: Western disturbance may hit on March 2, rain alert in 7 districts
articles.summary: The winter season is generally considered to end on 28 February. Intense sunshine has begun, leading to a rise in both day and night temperatures. Minimum temperatures are currently above average, resulting in less cold at night. Western disturbances this year have led to temperature fluctuations. The typical trend in March shows a more significant temperature increase in the second half of the month.

articles.title: Mumbai weather update: Here's why the city has been sizzling for last four days
articles.author: Dipti Singh
articles.summary: An anti-cyclone over Madhya Pradesh has been pushing warm air across the west coast, delaying the setting in of sea breeze and causing the mercury to soar. For four consecutive days, Mumbai has been reeling under intense heat, with temperatures soaring to 38.7°C on February 26. Other coastal regions, including Ratnagiri, Dahanu, and Goa's Panjim have also recorded unusually high temperatures. The India Meteorological Department attributes the unusual heat to an exceptionally dry winter. This year, India has experienced one of the driest winters.

articles.title: The Paris Agreement is a delusion
articles.author: Vincent Obisie-Orlu
articles.summary: A decade after the Paris Agreement, the implementation of the agreement is struggling to take hold. Fewer than 10% of signatories have submitted updated NDCs. Most of the world's population lives in developing countries, which bear the brunt of climate disasters despite historically contributing the least to the problem. Wealthy countries built their economies on the back of fossil fuels. They expect poorer nations to transition without having had the same opportunities for industrial growth. The long-promised annual $100 billion pledge must finally be met.

articles.title: Trump administration fires hundreds at agency that forecasts weather, hurricanes
articles.summary: NOAA monitors and forecasts the country's weather and hurricanes, administers oceanic fisheries, protects coastal resources, and creates and updates nautical maps used for global shipping. The cuts to NOAA will have far-reaching consequences, experts warn. There may be less accurate weather forecasts or delays in updating marine maps critical to safe transit through the United States' oceanic seas.

articles.title: Chandigarh records hottest Feb night in 14 years as mercury climbs to 18.5°C
articles.author: Hindustan Times
articles.summary: The city's night temperature rose to 18.5°C on the intervening night between Wednesday and Thursday, the highest in 14 years, as per India Meteorological Department (IMD). A woman and a boy were rescued by a passing car.

articles.title: Climate change threatens food system Nnaji
articles.author: The Sun
articles.summary: Chief Uche Nnaji made the statement at the Commonwealth Roundtable on Climate Finance & Food Security held at Marlborough house, London, United Kingdom. In Nigeria, rising temperatures and erratic weather patterns reduce agricultural yields and reduce food production.

articles.title: Cassowary, the only bird Australians are afraid of ' and how to stay safe
articles.author: Tribune
articles.summary: Cassowary is the only bird that Australians are afraid of, according to the Tribune Online article.  It might catch one by surprise to know that there is one animal that they fear in the same part of the world where they mostly dwell among jellyfish, snakes and spiders.

articles.title: The Indus River: A lifeline under threat
articles.author: Nadeem Mirbahar
articles.summary: The Indus River supplies water to Karachi, Sukkur, Larkana, Khairpur, Benazirabad, Hyderabad, Mirpur Khas, Sanghar, and Thatta. Rising temperatures and climate change are altering the river's flow and increasing the risk of long-term water shortages. Water shortages within Pakistan, particularly in Sindh, could escalate inter-provincial and federal disputes over water allocation.

articles.title: Climate Financing
articles.author: Daily Times
articles.summary: Pakistan is the fifth most vulnerable country to climate change. Islamabad is seeking $1.5 billion in climate financing from the International Monetary Fund. Pakistan contributes minimally to global carbon emissions, yet it bears the brunt of climate-related calamities. Children deserve a seat at the table when shaping policies that will affect their future environment and health.

articles.title: Albanese hit hard by live fire from all sides
articles.author: Jennifer Hewett
articles.summary: Aircraft are far more agile than Anthony Albanese in changing course to avoid the risk of being hit by China's live-fire drills in the Tasman Sea. The prime minister's stumbling attempts to explain when and how Australia learned of Chinese warships' aggressive moves makes it look like the government is flying blind in a dangerous world.

articles.title: Farmers face uncertain future as millions of dollars worth of sugar cane crops destroyed in floods
articles.author: Katharina Loesche
articles.summary: Up to $50 million worth of sugar cane crops have been destroyed by recent floods in Ingham, Queensland. The region was hit by relentless rains that caused widespread flooding, submerging fields and destroying infrastructure. This year, 70 per cent of the crop has been washed away. Many farmers will have no income this year, with no clear timeline for how long it will take the land to recover. The uncertainty surrounding the future of their farms is causing emotional strain, with many farmers beginning to experience mental health issues. The federal government has allocated $25,000 in Category C grants, but farmers want more.

articles.title: Demand for water resource calls for sustainable use interventions
articles.author: Joseph Prosper
articles.summary: Tanzania is endowed with abundant natural resources, including water. Water experts recommend using it sparingly and protecting its sources to meet growing demand for present and future generations. The government has been raising public awareness of the protection of water sources, especially in areas where farming takes place and where forests are cleared for human settlements. Some parts of the country have been reached by a national safe and clean water programme (tap water), but others still grapple with water scarcity.

articles.title: Environmental Imbalance and Climate Change: The Growing Threat
articles.summary: The Supreme Court of India has expressed concern over rampant deforestation. Sea ice has fallen to a record low of 15-76 million square kilometers. Global temperatures are rising, ocean currents are becoming unstable, and extreme weather events are intensifying. The impact of climate change on agriculture is becoming increasingly evident. Many communities are not prepared to face climate change threats.

articles.title: Egyptian mummies and steamy cities
articles.summary: Jack is filling in for Ruby this week. They are going to the pyramids of Egypt to see some mummies and hear about the urban heat island effect. Emma McKeon has won 14 Olympic medals. The new south Wales government bought a place called Broughton Vale Station, on Barkindji country. It's home to a sacred Aboriginal birthing site, called Burkes Caves, or Kukirrka. Dot Stephens, an elder from the area, is excited about turning it into a national park.

articles.title: Temperatures surge in GB Nagar, IMD says thunderstorms ahead
articles.author: Hindustan Times
articles.summary: Gautam Budh Nagar has experienced a rise in temperature over the past two days. The minimum temperature reached 17.3°C on Thursday, three degrees more than on Wednesday. The sudden rise in the temperature is making it uncomfortable, especially during the daytime.

articles.title: Living in extreme heat could make you age faster, study finds
articles.author: Stuti Mishra
articles.summary: Older adults living in hotter regions of the US showed signs of accelerated ageing at a cellular level, according to a new study published in Science Advances. Today at 21:30, UK Independent reports that the study claims that prolonged exposure to extreme heat could make you biologically older.

articles.title: Living in extreme heat could make you age faster, study finds
articles.author: Stuti Mishra
articles.summary: Extreme heat exposure could make you biologically older, according to a new study.    “Prolonged exposure to extreme heat could make people biologically older”.  “It could make them more susceptible to disease”   "It could also make them physically older".

articles.title: Climate change, Resilience and Sustainability Facility, and beyond
articles.author: Dr Omer Javed
articles.summary: Pakistan is one of the most climate change-vulnerable countries. The country has been affected by extreme weather over the last many years. Pakistan, Belize, and Italy were the most affected countries in 2022. Pakistan needs to invest in building resilience against catastrophes and building capacity for early monitoring of 'tipping points' that lead to climate catastrophe. There are around 16 tipping points.

articles.title: In North India, short winter doesn't always lead to searing summer
articles.author: Amit Bhattacharya
articles.summary: TOI analysed 54-year temperature data for north India to find that a warm February doesn't necessarily lead to a hotter than usual April. In 2023, north India experienced record heat in February but April was cooler than normal. In 2022, April in north India was the hottest on record, while temperatures in February were close to normal.

articles.title: Who controls the Murdoch family trust, good pie charts and the baby boom
articles.author: Nick Evershed
articles.summary: This week's edition of The Crunch has charts on the melting of glaciers, how the baby boom reshaped populations in many different countries, who controls the Murdoch family trust, how Germany's economic strength became a weakness and what it looks like to run the game Pong on hundreds of browser tabs.

articles.title: Hundreds of scientists and experts at key U.S. climate agency fired
articles.summary: Hundreds of scientists and experts have been fired from the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration. The cuts come as Elon Musk's Department of Government Efficiency enacts sweeping reductions to the federal workforce. NOAA has been a prime target for conservative ideologues behind Project 2025, a blueprint for governing. President Donald Trump's new administration appears to be following Project 2025.

articles.title: Portland's February temperature record broken, warmest weather since October 2024
articles.author: Josh Cozart
articles.summary: Portland breaks the record for warmest February 27 with a preliminary high of 68 degrees Thursday. It's the warmest temperature felt in Portland since October 20, 2024, when the high temperature was 69 degrees. Another round of record-breaking heat is possible on Friday as highs return to the mid to upper-60s.

articles.title: 'Farewell to the Godwits'
articles.author: Kees Chalmers
articles.summary: The godwits are leaving Christchurch's Avon-Heathcote Estuary on their annual 14,000km journey to Alaska. On Saturday, March 1, from 6-7pm about 500 people are set to gather at the Southshore Spit for the Farewell to the Godwits event. It is the longest bird migration in the world.

articles.title: Climate And Peace Agenda Implementation Under COP29 Presidency Kicks Off (PHOTO)
articles.author: MENA FN
articles.summary: Strategic Session of the Climate Change Vulnerable Countries Network organized in Baku, Azerbaijan, on February 27. The session is aimed at helping countries suffering from conflicts and humanitarian needs.      Â   in the context of the climate change.

articles.title: Wine grape growers demand safeguards for industry in 'crisis'
articles.author: system
articles.summary: Farmers in Australia's largest wine grape regions are calling on the federal government to implement a mandatory code of conduct immediately to stop a mass exodus of growers from the region. The farmers are calling for the code to be implemented immediately.   .   i

articles.title: Maine must prepare for storms and climate change, lawmakers told
articles.author: Journal Tribune
articles.summary: The proposal was presented at a legislative hearing on Thursday. It was formed in the wake of last winter's back-to-back storms. It will help communities prepare for bad weather and climate change, according to the proposal. It's a response to the recent winter storms.

articles.title: Lake Chad isn't shrinking — but climate change is causing other problems
articles.author: Mongabay
articles.summary: The Lake Chad Basin lies in the Sahel, on the southern edge of the Sahara. The basin covers 2.5 million square kilometers (965,255 square miles) or 8% of the African continent. The communities around Lake Chad have always lived by its water rhythms. Now they must find new ways to adapt to climate change impacts.

articles.title: Weatherwatch: marine ‘hot spot' could change makeup of British fish species
articles.author: The Guardian
articles.summary: Favourites such as cod, haddock and salmon could be replaced as UK waters warm up, according to scientists. The warming of the UK waters is a threat to the fish's existence, they warn. The problem is most likely due to climate change.

articles.title: Most Americans who experienced severe winter weather see climate change at work, poll shows
articles.author: TAMMY WEBBER
articles.summary: Matt Ries has lived in Florida for three years. Last summer was unusually hot, followed by three hurricanes in close succession. Then temperatures dropped below freezing for days this winter, and snow blanketed the area. Ries thinks it's obvious that the weather in Florida has changed.

articles.title: We now know how much emissions have delayed the next glacial period
articles.author: New Scientist
articles.summary: Changes in Earth's orbit drive long-term glacial cycles, but a new forecast suggests this ancient pattern is being disrupted for tens of thousands of years due to human-induced global warming, as predicted by the new forecast.   Â

articles.title: Europe's Greens have the blues as climate measures rolled back
articles.author: The Banner-Press
articles.summary: Europe's Greens are dismayed as Brussels unpicks part of the climate fight in the name of spurring growth. They fear it may just be the beginning of the end for the fight against climate change in Europe and for the whole of the world.

articles.title: Scientists Predict New Ice Age in 11,000 Years
articles.author: Colombia One
articles.summary: For nearly a million years, Earth's climate has shifted between freezing ice ages and warmer periods. Under natural conditions, another ice age would begin in about 11,000 years. However, rising global temperatures are thought to be the main cause of the current shift.

articles.title: Next Ice Age Should Be 10,000 Years Away – But Humans May Disrupt That
articles.author: IFL Science
articles.summary: For millions of years, Earth has experienced glacial periods followed by warmer periods. The orbital motion of our planet might play a crucial role in these changes. Researchers have been able to independently reconstruct the glacial period over the last million years. They found a predictable pattern for the timing of when Earth's climate changes between glacial 'ice ages' and mild warm periods like today.

articles.title: 3 million people displaces in Afghanistan due to Climate Disasters, 11 million at risk, warns IOM
articles.author: Khaama Press
articles.summary: Nearly 3 million people have been displaced in Afghanistan due to climate disasters since 2021. 11 million people are still at high risk. Nearly 9 million people in Afghanistan have been affected by climate-related disasters in the past year. Poor critical infrastructure weakens disaster preparedness and response, increasing vulnerability to climate hazards.

articles.title: Regional and context-specific approaches can improve study of marine heat waves
articles.author: Phys Dot Org

articles.title: Chicken bones and distorting timelines
articles.author: The Guardian
articles.summary: The size and abundance of chicken bones in strata don't herald a precisely defined'start' of the Anthropocene, says Matthew Edgeworth, and it's not a sign of the start of a new era of human activity. It's just something to keep an eye on.

articles.title: Scientists blast EPA's push to reverse key greenhouse gas finding
articles.author: Fast Company
articles.summary: Donald Trump's administration is trying to reverse a cornerstone finding that climate change endangers human health and welfare. Scientists say it's obvious how bad global warming is and how it's getting worse. New research and ever more frequent extreme weather are to blame for it.

articles.title: A looming ice age? Scientists find a striking pattern in Earth's history.
articles.author: Usatoday
articles.summary: An ice age should begin in about 10,000 years, but its onset is most likely delayed due to man-made climate change, according to an international team of scientists. They were amazed to find such a clear imprint of the different orbital parameters on the climate record.

articles.title: Uplifting women for climate resilience
articles.author: Sadia Ishrat Satti
articles.summary: The world faces a significant challenge in addressing climate change. Developing countries bear the brunt of climate impacts, including increased frequency of natural disasters, disrupted livelihoods, and exacerbated health issues. Climate change has a disproportionate impact on women, exacerbated by deep-seated gender inequalities and societal norms that heighten their vulnerability. Pakistan has requested $1.5 billion from the IMF for climate finance.

articles.title: Over 500,000 Afghans displaced due to climate disasters in 2024: IOM
articles.author: AFP
articles.summary: More than half a million people in Afghanistan were displaced due to climate disasters in 2024. Afghanistan is among the poorest countries in the world after decades of war and is ranked the sixth most vulnerable to climate change. 39 people were killed this week due to floods, hail and storms in southwestern Afghanistan.

articles.title: Study reveals how Earth's orbit controls ice ages

articles.title: Light rain in Northwestern Madhya Pradesh likely in early March
articles.author: BHOPAL
articles.summary: A new Western Disturbance is expected to become active from March 2, increasing the possibility of light rainfall in the northwestern part of Madhya Pradesh during the first week of March. Both day and night temperatures are expected to rise by 2 to 3 degrees Celsius for the next three days. On Wednesday, Bhopal remained cloudy since morning, while weather fluctuations were observed in Rewa, Satna, Panna, and Maihar districts.

articles.title: Pointing out threats to our fragile coastline
articles.author: Environmental advocacy
articles.summary: Environmental advocacy group Wild Ones warned Town of Hempstead residents about the dangers of Long Island's changing coastlines during an informational session on Feb. 22. The presentation was directed to all Long Island residents. Long Island was hit by Superstorm Sandy in 2012, eroding beaches, flooding coastal houses and causing $19 billion in damage to the New York metropolitan area.

Long Island's shorelines were hammered by Superstorm Sandy in 2012, eroding beaches and flooding coastal houses. Since then, shoreline communities need better protection to avoid harm. articles.title: Scientists scorn EPA push to say climate change isn't a danger, say just look around at the world
articles.author: Seth Borenstein
articles.summary: Trump's administration is trying to reverse a cornerstone finding that climate change endangers human health and welfare. Scientists say it's obvious how bad global warming is and how it's getting worse, and it's not going to get better under Trump's administration's policies.
